text: frank zappa here hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here internets busiest
music nerd and it's time for a review
continuing reviews of some of my
favorite albums ever classics if you
want to use the c-word this is not going
to be a regular segment I'm only doing
it for this week my heart is just not
into constantly reviewing older albums
I'd much rather focus on new stuff
because that's what I cares about the
mostest
I respect the past but I don't live in
it however there's no reason we can't
you know do this just right now to
celebrate 50k right so to continue this
week I would love to talk about the
Frank Zappa album hot rats Frank Zappa
guitarist composer singer rock icon and
musical eccentric any conversation
focusing on the weirder side of American
music should at least mention Frank
Zappa for sure not only has the guy
written a plethora a plethora of
experimental music over the course of
his career but there are some serious
musical chops to be found in his
discography but I think the most
memorable attribute Zappa had to offer
in his music was definitely his
personality when I think of Frank
Zappa's personality and how it fits into
his music it's almost as if a musician
from the 2000s had got transported back
to the 1960s and 70s because of the
sheer level of self-awareness that Zappa
put into his music he was a guy that
just loved to make fun of everything
including what he did for a living he
laced his humor and his worldview in his
music at just about every opportunity
that he could zappa's music poked fun at
hippies and the 60s on the seminal album
were only in it for the money
and less than ten years later on Zoop
the lures he was making fun of the disco
set and his other albums are also loaded
with
about teen angst and love and sex and
rock and roll as well as Fame and
societal norms however how rats is where
a lot of the joking gets kind of cast
aside in order to create a set of mostly
instrumental and exceptional jazz rock
and jazz fusion songs which maybe the
most widely admired and known in the
genre Zappa was not the only guy playing
with these ideas at the time though he
had plenty of contemporaries fusing jazz
with rock funk an avant-garde
composition like Miles Davis
Santana Herbie Hancock let's not forget
the soft machine as well as one of my
all-time favorites the Mahavishnu
Orchestra but Zappa's jazz rock tracks
have a much different attitude than the
songs of those artists were were putting
together I know I said on this record
earlier the joking kind of gets put
aside but the sound the style the the
feelings that get conveyed on this album
are so much brighter and more fun and
kookier in comparison to those artists
which is not usually something Rock and
especially jazz fans smile upon since
jazz and rocker really deep and really
sure your genres of music but Zappa's
compositional chops and his is playing
on this record are so great it's hard
not to admire what's going on here on at
least some level if you don't come away
from hot rats loving the entire album I
think at least the first track is is
worth loving
or maybe liking this song peaches in
regalia starts with a rush of piano
chords and what kind of sounds like
speedily tremolo picked guitar leads I'm
not completely sure how that sound is
created to be quite honest I know in the
past Zappa has experimented with
recording guitar solos to tape and then
altering the speed of the tape in order
to get an interesting effect I'm not
sure if that's what's going on here but
whatever it is it's a really interesting
sound and gives peaches of flavor that
right after this introductory moment
brass and woodwinds kind of fly in and
it's not like there's any instrument in
this spot that hasn't been on another
record clarinet saxophone that sort of
thing but the way they were kind of
pancaked onto one another
it creates an interesting sound an
interesting tone it's almost as if one
instrument is creating this sound and it
just ends up being so memorable because
of that because of how strange and odd
the instruments feel on here and of
course Zapp is unique approach to
writing melodies only helps that after
this some flute and keyboard and guitar
kind of alternate for the soloing
spotlight on this track and then just
before the two-minute mark there's just
this Jubilee of bright bright horns that
are just so triumphant they come off as
being equal parts beautiful and quirky
with a really close listen it becomes
kind of apparent that this song is
really really composed very planned out
but it's great because Zappa and the
musicians he brought on to this record
Jam it out so fluidly it's almost as if
it's just stream of consciousness this
song is definitely noticeable peak in
the Zappa discography in this album
it's really zappas compositional side at
its sharpest after the opener things get
dirtier looser more kind of jammed out
if you're expecting you know one kind of
meticulously composed jazz rock opus
after another you're just not going to
get that the rest of the tracks on here
have spots that are clearly planned out
- just like peaches especially the song
son of mr. Greenjeans which is almost
the cousin to peaches but most of the
remaining songs on here are much longer
because they're they're stretched out
with solos and improv and that's great
for jazz fans and people who love jazz
fusion and guitar heroism but maybe not
for people who love their songs short
sweet simple to the point
still I like all the songs following the
opener on this thing and the grittiest
of all of them comes right after the
opener Willie the pimp which features
the gravel-voiced Captain Beefheart a
predecessor to Tom Waits and he is not
shy on this track at all sort of
lyrically painting this image of a pimp
and shouting and shrieking all over this
track like he's really causing a ruckus
and just the the groove and the solos
just the jam of this track just feels so
loaded down and and dirty this track is
about as filthy as a whorehouse mattress
I would say and there's this really
sleazy fiddle playing all over this song
which really brings that attitude home
things head back in the direction of
refinement on the song the son of mr.
Greenjeans which like I said is heavily
layered and orchestrated just like
peaches and regalia but on this song
things really get stretched out with a
lot of strong soloing and Zappa's
playing is just so great on this track I
can't help but eat up every note he was
just such a great player the guitar was
almost an extension of him you can
really kind of dive into what he's
playing and think about it and see that
it's thoughtful but it's so fast and
fluid it's almost as if it had no
planning or forethought whatsoever
following that song is little umbrellas
which because of its lack of just
blaring guitar solos is almost just a
legit jazz song simply jazz not jazz
rock almost a jazz song because this
track is mostly made of composed moments
my one real annoyance with this album is
that I feel like little umbrellas could
have been so much longer if it had been
jammed out this song really isn't as
stretched out as it could be and I think
it's worth stretching out because the
feeling of this track is so much
different than the other songs it's more
chilled out it kind of lurches forward
and it's really kind of sad and
mysterious way I'd say it's a lovable
monstrous
but the lack of strong soloing on that
song is made up for on the next track
here
that song is gumbo variations where Ian
Underwood whips out his most fiery
performance yet on this album his sax
screams for mercy on this song this
thing is a 17 minute long combo of jazz
funk and rock all the composing and all
the planning sort of gets thrown to the
curb as saxophone violin and guitar just
placed so hard that even I get sweaty
the closer it must be a camel kind of
sends things off on a really weird note
saxophones and drums kind of hit these
syncopated angular jagged melodies it's
twice the monstrosity of little
umbrellas and has a lot more beef to it
as well I would just like to say I love
the hell out of this album and hot rats
is just a standout moment in not just
the Zappa discography but in jazz fusion
and jazz rock in general I wouldn't say
other albums in this style are inferior
definitely not but this is one of the
only albums that I know that combines
jazz and rock with these really
colorfully eccentric compositions so if
you really value a strong personality
unique melody writing jazz this may
become a classic for you just as it is
for me this thing is definitely one of
my favorites and probably will be for
